My chessistic experience (however good) told me that I can have a confident try in resisting black's pressure on the queenside. Let's see if it is true.
!? Right into the danger. But the support the rook gives to the center will be helpful.

Contesting the center, specially d4, and keeping in mind the possibility of an exchange. My bishop can't leave the diagonal controlling h6.
Interesting reaction by black. Now his attack on the queenside is momentarily stopped. Good.
I though hard to Nd4, probably better. I admit I was tempting him.
He took the bite.
What a way to lose an attack! But I thought this little pawn in e6 would have had a future. It hadn't. If BxN, black can go hxN, and it is hard to analyze.
Wise, since BxN was coming. I don't care at all if black does me the favour to take Bxg2.
